dt: {bc}to be able or designed to take or hold (something applied or added)

dt.t: a surface that will not {wi}accept{/wi} ink
{wi}accept{/wi} her as one of the group
a heart more disposed to {wi}accept{/wi} of his

quotes.t: When Bess was born, my mother had a hard time {qword}accepting{/qword} many of our parenting choices.

Despite Alexander's general skepticism about speed measurements, he does {qword}accept{/qword} the cheetah as probably the fastest known running species. The measurement he finds most reliable, 29 m/s (about 65 mph), comes from a 1997 record along a 200-meter course clocked by an experienced timekeeper for athletic races.
The Edinburgh Christ in the House of Martha and Mary doesn't look like a Vermeer, although its signature has been {qword}accepted{/qword} as genuine.

et: Middle English {it}accepten{/it} "to receive graciously, favor, approve of, judge worthy," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}accepter{/it}, borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}acceptāre{/it}, going back to Latin, "to receive regularly, submit to, admit of," frequentative of {it}accipere{/it} "to take, receive, accept, learn, interpret," from {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-} + {it}capere{/it} "to take" {ma}{mat|heave:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to be able or designed to take or hold (something applied or added)
to give admittance or approval to

dt: {bc}to agree to publish (something) and make it available to the public

dt.t: My novel has been {it}accepted for publication{/it}.

shortdef: to agree to publish (something) and make it available to the public

dt.t: He was unwilling to {it}accept{/it} {it}that{/it} he could no longer play as he once had.
He has to {it}accept the fact that{/it} his baseball career is over.
These myths are {it}accepted/taken as gospel{/it} by many teenagers.

dt: {bc}to accept (something) as true without proof or evidence that it is true

dt.t: I'm not willing to {it}take{/it} her statements {it}on faith{/it}.
I'll {it}accept{/it} it {it}on faith{/it} that he knows the truth.

shortdef: to accept (something) as true without proof or evidence that it is true
